webTitle: Saint Jude storm lifts B&Q sales as householders fork out for fence panels

fields.standfirst: Sales rise 4.6% in latest quarter but shares slide as profits disappoint and trading conditions worsen in France
fields.body:
Sales of fence panels and water pumps in the wake of the Saint Jude storm helped performance at B&Q owner Kingfisher, which revealed a 4.6% rise in sales in the quarter to 2 November.

Fence panel sales rose 41% while water pumps rose 63% in the week after high winds hit Britain last month, helping to maintain growth in underlying sales at B&Q despite the ongoing squeeze on disposable incomes.

But shares in Kingfisher slid 4.4% to 378.5p as profits came in at the low end of City expectations at £271m – a rise of 5.8% – while chief executive Ian Cheshire warned of tough trading conditions in France, Kingfisher's most profitable territory.

"Consumer confidence is still weak and with no obvious signs of an imminent improvement," he said.

Underlying sales in France were flat and profits down 5.6% once currency fluctuations were accounted for, amid heavy discounting among DIY retailers as the country's housing market continued to contract.

Analysts were concerned that B&Q's underlying sales were virtually flat, at 0.4%, as sales of DIY products continued to suffer despite signs of a pick-up in the UK housing market.

Cheshire said DIY was suffering because shoppers still had little spare cash as inflation continued to outstrip wage rises. He said sales to tradesmen were performing better because "white van man" was benefiting from a boom in construction thanks to the Help to Buy scheme.

But he said DIY sales were more reliant on a strong market for older houses, and that had yet to see real growth.

However, strong profits in other overseas markets, particularly Poland and Russia, as well as impressive growth at Kingfisher's multi-channel business Screwfix, helped lift total group profits by 1.7% at constant currency rates and 5.8% overall to £271m for the quarter.

webTitle: Hedge fund sells up after forcing Co-op to cede control of bank

fields.bodyText: One of the US hedge funds which forced the Co-operative Group to cede control of its troubled bank has sold its investment ahead of a crucial vote on a rescue £1.5bn fundraising. Just hours after the Co-operative Bank admitted it was losing current accounts because of concerns over its future as an ethical institution amid the intervention of hedge funds and the scandal over former chairman Paul Flowers, it emerged that the US hedge fund Aurelius had sold its position in the bank's bonds. Aurelius – best known for forcing Argentina to pay out on its debts – had bought up Co-op bonds as they collapsed in value following the downgrade of the bank to junk status in May. Since then the bonds have risen in value and have now been sold on to another hedge fund, London-based Perry Capital. Perry pledged to continue backing the crucial restructuring of the bank just hours before Friday's deadline to vote on the deal. The so-called LT2 group of hedge funds, which included Aurelius and has forced the changes on the Co-op Group, made no reference to the crucial change in its membership when it reiterated its support for the restructuring on Thursday morning. If bondholders vote to back the restructuring of the bank, the wider Co-op Group, which includes supermarkets and funeral homes, will end up with just a 30% stake in the bank that bears its name. The deadline for votes is 4.30pm on Friday. The Co-op, in an unscheduled announcement outlining technical changes to the terms offered to LT2, insisted that its savers – whom it relies on to finance its business – were not moving their cash out of the bank and its deposit base remained stable. Flowers is on bail until January after being arrested following a Mail on Sunday report that showed a video of the 63-year-old Methodist minister handing over cash to apparently buy drugs. Even before Flowers' arrest there was concern that the intervention of hedge funds in the Co-op fundraising could make it difficult for the bank to maintain its ethical stance. "These recent events, together with the competitive landscape in which the bank operates, the introduction of seven-day account switching and the associated increased competitor marketing activity at a time when the bank has been constrained in its ability to undertake its own marketing activity, may be a contributing factor to an increase the bank has seen in the switching out of current accounts," Co-op said. The wording is tougher than that in the prospectus sent to bondholders on 4 November to back the restructuring when it referred to a "material reduction" in the number of people moving their accounts to the bank since the seven-day switching service was introduced in September. At that time it said corporate customers had taken away £1.4bn worth of deposits since the ratings downgrade in May. The admission by the Co-op bank came as its regulator, Andrew Bailey, chief executive of the Prudential Regulation Authority, said the regulatory approval granted to enable Flowers to become chairman in 2010 was "before his time". Bailey, who took over the top regulation job in the summer of 2011, said he had required the Co-op bank board to be strengthened and had set out hurdles for the bank to meet if it was to be granted approval for the takeover of 631 branches from Lloyds Banking Group. That deal, called Verde, collapsed this year. Bailey insisted he did not "know the whole story" about what had happened or about any potential intervention from politicians keen to see the Co-op take over the Lloyds' branches. He added: "The real important thing today is not to deal with Reverend Flowers's antics but to deal with stabilisation and restructuring of the bank." Lord Myners, City minister during the 2008 banking crisis, called for institutional investors to be represented when bank directors are appointed. "We need a fundamental change in accountability and alignment within the board room. Shareholders had got off scot-free when it came to culpability for bank failures and the cost to the economy," Myners said. Lloyds looks to lord The Conservative peer Lord Blackwell is the leading candidate to become the next chairman of the bailed-out Lloyds Banking Group. The former head of Sir John Major's policy unit, and a serial non-executive director, already has a seat on the bank's board and chairs its insurance arm Scottish Widows. He previously sat on the board of Standard Life and retailers Dixons and was once a partner at the management consultants McKinsey. The bank, whose chief executive, António Horta-Osório, received a £2.3m bonus last week because of the rally in its shares, has been seeking a successor to Sir Win Bischoff who wants to retire at next year's annual meeting. The government began to sell its stake in Lloyds in September and now owns a 32% shareholding, which is expected to fall further before the general election through a sell-off to retail investors. Lloyds would not comment on its next chairman on Thursday.

webTitle: Tesco accused of squeezing suppliers to support its profits

fields.standfirst: Britain's biggest supermarket alleged to have written letters demanding money from suppliers' trading accounts
fields.body:
Tesco has been accused of squeezing suppliers to support its profits ahead of an anticipated grim trading update next week.

Mike Dennis, an analyst at stockbroker Cantor Fitzgerald, suggested that Britain's biggest supermarket had written letters demanding money from suppliers' trading accounts – where payments are deposited by Tesco – to support its short-term profit margins.

He said that such activity risked breaching the groceries supply code of practice, which governs dealing between big supermarkets and their direct suppliers.

He said: "It is our view that Tesco has again overstepped the mark and the situation is very difficult for many suppliers."

Tesco said Dennis's assertions were "based on speculation" and it had not broken the code. But it did not specifically deny the allegation that it had recently demanded or taken money from suppliers.

A spokesman said: "In our interim results presentation last month, we set out how the general merchandise transformation programme will be a drag on our sales growth but beneficial to the overall UK margin, helping to offset some of the other investments we are making for customers."

The office of the groceries code adjudicator, Christine Tacon, said she had not received any complaints about Tesco demanding cash from suppliers but would be looking into the accusations.

A spokesperson said: "Where we do hear reports about possible issues surrounding the code, we will look to follow up with the retailers concerned.

"It's obviously too early to conclude whether there has been any breach but we will want to find out more about the circumstances."

Tacon is consulting on the guidance for investigations and enforcement of the code, which may involve fines of up to £1bn for serious breaches. She is expected to publish her recommendations before Christmas and formal investigation can take place before then.

There was no suggestion that Tesco could or should face such an investigation, with probes only expected to be launched in extreme circumstances.

Several retail analysts said that Tesco could use a number of different strategies to meet its promise of maintaining UK profit margins despite an expected 1.5% or 2% fall in underlying sales during the three months to the end of November.

For example, the supermarket has been gradually reducing its sales of less profitable electrical items such as televisions and been heavily promoting more profitable lines such as its premium own-label Finest food range.

Andrew Kasoulis, an analyst at Credit Suisse, said: "Price cuts and negative sales volumes do, of course, weigh on margin, but improving fresh [food] sales, the Finest re-launch, more convenience stores, downsizing non-food, successful refits and less money-off coupons this year are all positive for margin."

He said Tesco's anticipated 5.2% UK margin target for this year could be the result of multiple factors and not necessarily the result of putting pressure on suppliers.

Tesco's management team are under pressure as its underlying sales fall around the world. In Britain it is losing business to upmarket rivals such as Waitrose and hard discounters like Aldi and Lidl.

It is also struggling with the move away from big weekly shopping trips at hypermarkets and a shift to online shopping.

webTitle: Bank of England steps in amid fears of a new house price bubble

fields.bodyText: The governor of the Bank of England on Thursday reined in the mortgage market as he sought to prevent five years of ultra-low interest rates and George Osborne's Help to Buy scheme from fuelling a pre-election housing bubble. Amid concerns that the UK is in the early stages of a new property boom, Mark Carney announced he was refocusing the Funding for Lending (FLS) scheme that gave lenders financial incentives to provide home loans. The governor said it was "no longer appropriate or necessary for us to have our foot on the accelerator, better to shift into neutral". He said it was time to focus FLS on small businesses. The decision had been taken with the chancellor, he said. "By acting now in a graduated fashion, authorities are reducing the likelihood that larger interventions will be needed later," Carney said. The governor stressed that the housing market is not an immediate risk to financial stability. But he admitted that financial policymakers were concerned about the "prospective evolution" of the market amid forecasts of a 10% rise in house prices next year on top of a near-7% increase in the past 12 months. The TUC said the move would "hit the feelgood factor" Osborne has been trying to create before the 2015 general election and prompted speculation that the move to end a key part of the FLS had been taken reluctantly by the chancellor. Osborne said: "Now the housing market is starting to pick up, it is right we focus the scheme's firepower on small businesses. Small firms are the lifeblood of our economy." Some economists were sceptical that the withdrawal of the FLS would have a major impact. Others warned it could spell the end of the low mortgage rates that customers have enjoyed and that are said to be helping to propel house prices higher. More than £1bn was wiped off the value of housebuilders after Carney's remarks – Barratt Developments fell almost 10% and Persimmon 6% – on fears that ending FLS might backfire. Sterling rose on expectations of interest-rate rises, although economist James Knightly at City bank ING said the aim of the policymakers was to have the opposite effect. The FLS provided an immediate boost to mortgage lending when it launched in August 2012 and has since been supplemented by the chancellor's Help to Buy scheme, which offers subsidised home loans up to £600,000. Help to Buy will be unaffected by the package of measures announced by the Bank of England on Thursday. Other changes designed to keep a close watch on the housing market include imposing tougher "affordability" tests on consumers before they are granted home loans and ensuring that annual financial health checks on banks include the impact of major shocks in the housing market. The surprise move to refocus FLS means that until the scheme ends, in January 2015, it will now be used only for business loans. The FLS for home loans will end a year earlier than planned, in January 2014. Cathy Jamieson, shadow financial secretary to the Treasury, said: "We called for the (FLS) to prioritise lending to business, and, after three wasted years when net lending to firms has fallen, the government is belatedly acting. But homeowners facing a cost-of-living crisis will want reassurance from ministers that suddenly taking the scheme away from mortgage lending won't see a rise in mortgage rates." Business secretary Vince Cable said the changes to FLS were "sensible and welcome", adding: "It is critical it supports growth in the productive economy, rather than simply stoke the housing market." In a letter to Osborne, Carney said: "Although the growth in household loan volumes remains modest, activity is picking up and house price momentum appears to be gaining momentum." But there were no changes to the Help to Buy scheme, which the Bank will assess annually from 2014. In Thursday's half-yearly check on the risks to financial stability, the Bank said activity in the housing market remains below long-term trends. The Bank's financial stability review spelled out the impact that rate rises could have on the most vulnerable households, who have taken on mortgages at high multiples of their incomes and over periods of more than 25 years. The Bank of England said it was putting "several actions in train that will guard against a build-up in vulnerabilities". New mortgage affordability tests will be introduced from April 2014. Frances O'Grady, general secretary of the TUC, said: "This is good news for the real economy, but bad news for the chancellor. The Bank of England is clearly worried that the economic recovery is based on consumers borrowing on the back of rising house prices rather than business investment and rising exports. "Ensuring that Funding for Lending works to boost business investment is a sensible policy that can drive sustainable growth and help build a new economy. But stopping over-excitement in the property market may hit the feelgood factor that the chancellor is hoping will distract from the failure of government policy to rebalance the economy." The Bank said a key risk to financial stability could be caused by an abrupt rise in long-term interest rates, and the Financial Conduct Authority is working with banks and other firms to ensure they are prepared for this risk. Public sector indebtedness has also risen since the crisis and some households remain vulnerable. "Financial stability risks remain, including from the high indebtedness of some sovereigns, corporates and households. These vulnerabilities have been kept in check by low interest rates and other policy interventions," the financial stability report said.

webTitle: Thomas Cook still looking buoyant as Wave 2 cost savings commence

fields.standfirst: Shares have enjoyed mighty recovery since chief executive Harriet Green joined and new move should continue good work
fields.body:
Best recovery stock of recent years? It's no contest. Thomas Cook's shares stood at 14p when Harriet Green arrived in summer 2012; they were still under 50p at the start of this year; and now they are 176p, up 15%.

The latest bout of enthusiasm was prompted by Green's declaration that she can find another hefty helping of cost savings to add to an original serving that has been consistently increased to the point where it has hit £440m. The next batch will be "of a similar scale".

Wave 2, as Green calls it, will be harder to achieve than Wave 1, which rested on the rapid removal of 2,500 jobs. It involves the messy business of integrating the back-office functions of Thomas Cook's pan-European empire, a task unforgivably left undone by past management that was happier pursuing a debt-fuelled acquisition strategy.

Wave 2 will cost more and take longer to achieve – the dial is set for 2018. There is no shame in that as curing such an under-managed company was always going to take longer than simply saving it via a credible management plan and a £1.6bn recapitalisation.

But Thomas Cook – waving, not drowning in debt, as it were – is clearly now in a position to pursue the ultimate prize of generating respectable profit margins from group-wide annual revenues of £9bn.

In the UK last year profit margins at the level of earnings before interest and tax were a miserable 2.2%, for example. So the first operating profit at Thomas Cook since 2010 (a mere £13m) will indeed be "just the start" if Green gets her plan right.

The share price can only slow down after the excitements of the past 18 months, and the cost of restructuring should not be ignored. But, on current form, the momentum is still with Green.

webTitle: High street unveils American-style 'Black Friday' shopping bonanza

fields.bodyText: The Christmas shopping season will kick off in earnest as British retailers bid to kickstart spending by adopting the American tradition of "Black Friday" discounting. The first weekend in December is always a high spending period as the nation collects its last pay packet before Christmas Day. Online retailers are used to seeing a surge in sales on "Cyber Sunday" and "Mega Monday" as shoppers try to ensure they get the presents they want delivered in time for the big day. But now the US tradition of Black Friday, the day after Thanksgiving when shops slash prices to encourage sales, is gathering pace in the UK. It is being driven by US retailers with a foot on this side of the Atlantic including Apple, Amazon and Asda, which are offering special discounts. Amazon has been offering discounts all week while Asda, owned by US retailer Walmart, is planning a sale in its stores including offers of up to 70% off a range of products including plasma TVs and tablets. John Lewis is running a one-day Black Friday sale in stores and online partly because Apple will be offering discounts and its "never knowingly undersold" price pledge means it must match cheaper prices elsewhere. Apple's iPad Air is expected to be one of the department store's bestsellers this Christmas. Andrew Moore, Asda's chief merchandising officer for general goods, said: "The last weekend in November is always a critical trading period in retail and with our Black Friday deals – a first for a UK supermarket – we're anticipating the busiest shopping day of the year so far." He said Asda would also be offering online deals on Monday. The focus on discounting during retailers' biggest sales period when many stores make the majority of their annual profits is a risky new trend. It comes as retailers expect shoppers to spend £40.3bn in the runup to Christmas. That total is just 3.5% more than last year, as wage rises have failed to keep up with inflation. More than 25m British consumers are expected to spend in pre-Christmas sales this year, spending an average £174 each according to research from RedEye, which claims that more than half of shoppers will shun the January sales in favour of finding discounts in November and December. "Black Friday has really caught the imagination of our customers. Last year we felt they really engaged with it and so we would go a step further." webTitle: Network Rail could be fined £80m after infrastructure faults cause rise in delays

fields.standfirst: Office of Rail Regulation says firm to blame for more than half of delays and points to £1.2bn underspending on maintenance
fields.body:
Network Rail faces a fine of up to £80m if it does not address worsening punctuality on the railways brought about by a £1.2bn underspend on maintenance, the industry regulator has warned.

The Office of Rail Regulation said the operator of Britain's rail infrastructure was responsible for more than half the delays on the network, and half of those were from problems in infrastructure.

It said deferring work and neglecting maintenance had contributed to a 5% rise in infrastructure failings to almost 16,000 incidents between April and October.

The ORR said that while Network Rail had made progress in reducing some types of delays, analysis published on Thursday showed that track, telecoms and cable faults were increasing.

Network Rail missed some punctuality targets by between 0.9 and 5.1 percentage points, it said, with long-distance train services the worst affected.

The regulator said 27,000 long-distance train services were either cancelled or more than 10 minutes late over the year, with only 86.6% on time – a performance that could lead to the imposition of an £80m fine.

The ORR pointed to the failure to spend nearly £1.2bn allocated for maintenance and renewal over the last four years.

Alan Price, the ORR's director of railway planning and performance, said: "Safety has to be Network Rail's top priority. Beyond that, its focus should be on delivering improved performance and increased capacity on the railways.

"The company is currently operating with a large underspend and a significant shortfall against the performance targets it signed up to. It is also behind schedule on its own maintenance and renewal plans. These factors are now contributing to delays to rail passenger and freight services."

The ORR said routine maintenance activity on track had fallen by about 30-40% since 2007.

Rail union RMT said the ORR's findings backed their warnings about maintenance cuts, but said the regulator should also shoulder the blame.

Its general secretary, Bob Crow, said: "The report makes it clear that major delays to services are wholly bound up with Network Rail's deferral of works for parts of the rail network such as tracks, level crossings and electrification. That is a shocking indictment on the state of Britain's railways while the private train operators are creaming off a fortune."

But he added: "Only last month the ORR demanded a further £1.7bn of cuts from Network Rail, cuts which would hack back skeleton staffing levels and drag back maintenance and renewals even further.

"ORR have got a nerve complaining about the impact of the cuts on one hand and then doling out another bunch with the other."

A Network Rail spokesman said it acknowledged it was not hitting regulatory targets, but had opted to keep services running rather than cancelling trains to meet targets, in the interests of passengers.

He said: "The real issue here is capacity and a largely Victorian infrastructure being pushed to its limits. Asset failures make up a small proportion of why trains are late. Our railway is congested and any incident – be it track, train or trespass – has massive knock-on effects.

"We believe our regulator needs to help us to address this capacity issue rather than focus exclusively on one narrow punctuality target."

webTitle: Royal Mail shares: Goldman Sachs sets price target of 610p

fields.standfirst: Row over privatisation may escalate over 12-month target after bank had advised government to float business at just 330p
fields.body:
Goldman Sachs has risked a further escalation of the Royal Mail privatisation row by putting a price target on the shares of 610p despite telling the government that the business should be floated at 330p last month.

Analysts at Goldman said the postal group's valuation should benefit from an increase in parcel deliveries, despite falling letter volumes.

The investment bank's 12-month price target of 610p represents an 85% premium on the flotation price, and gave further ammunition to those critics of the privatisation who argue the government sold off Royal Mail too cheaply.

Chuka Umunna, the shadow business secretary, said: "This raises yet more questions for ministers on their apparent failure to secure maximum value for the taxpayer in the Royal Mail fire sale.

"While Vince Cable has dismissed concerns that taxpayers may have been short-changed by hundreds of millions of pounds as 'froth', analysts at the bank which advised the deal are predicting that it could rise still further."

If Goldman is correct the company's value would rise to just above £6bn in a year's time, compared with its flotation value of £3.3bn.

Meanwhile Adrian Bailey, chairman of the business, innovations and skills committee, said there were "further questions that need to be asked" following the publication of the Goldman note.

"It confirms I think all the suspicions that between what the advisers were telling the government and what the advisers really felt was the potential of the company there was an enormous variation," Bailey told IB Times.

He added: "You have to question why there is this analysis now and another analysis at a much lower price that they defended vigorously only just over a week ago. What's happened that's different and what information is different now than what they had before?"

The analysts who produced the note are separate from the bankers who advised the government on the sale.

Goldman analysts, who gave Royal Mail a "neutral" rating, predicted a 7.7% rise in annual UK parcel revenues between 2013 and 2017, largely as a result of growth in online shopping. They predicted parcels will account for 57% of group revenues in 2017, up from 48% in 2013.

"With further modest growth coming from EU parcels we expect group parcel growth to more than offset continued letter volume declines," analysts said in the note.

"We forecast network modernisation (parcel automation and logistics optimisation) to drive productivity improvements and facilitate headcount reduction, delivering further margin improvement."

On the other hand, letter volumes are expected to decrease by 5.1% a year over the period.

Goldman said its analysis did not include the threat of future strike action by Royal Mail workers, considering the short-term risk of a strike as relatively low, although it acknowledged the potential for industrial action could be an ongoing investment risk. The threat of strike action has been cited by Cable as one of the reasons why the shares were sold at no higher than 330p.

Goldman added that other risks included a faster than expected decline in letter volumes, a delay in cost cutting, and proposed European Union data protection legislation, which could limit the ability of companies to engage in direct marketing.

Cable insisted on Wednesday that Royal Mail had not been sold too cheaply when questioned by members of the BIS committee.

Cable and Michael Fallon, the business minister who handled the flotation, said they decided against increasing the sale price by 20p a share because the market was already jittery over a potential US debt default.

Senior executives from Goldman were among those to be questioned last week by the same committee, over their role in advising the government on the flotation.

Royal Mail shares surged by more than a third on the first day of trading and have risen further since then to more than 560p.

webTitle: RSA Ireland head quits insurance firm and claims he was made 'fall guy'

fields.standfirst: Philip Smith says he has no option but to resign after being suspended amid alleged accounting irregularities
fields.body:
The head of RSA's Irish business has quit the insurer after claiming he was made the "fall guy" following allegations of accounting irregularities in the division.

Philip Smith said he had been "traumatised" by events that led to his suspension by the FTSE 100 company this month. Smith was relieved of his responsibilities after the company identified "issues" in the country's claims and finance functions that required an emergency €100m (£83m) capital injection into the unit.

RSA Ireland's chief financial officer, Rory O'Connor, and claims director, Peter Burke, were also suspended at the same time.

"I am certain that, when the recent issues arose, I quickly became the 'fall guy' for all issues. It is my firm belief that this opinion was arrived at irrespective of my involvement or otherwise, making it impossible for me to achieve justice and fairness. I have therefore been left with no other option but to resign," Smith said in a statement.

The 45-year old, who had led the Irish operation since 2007, insisted that he had worked to the best of his professional judgement and integrity.

He added: "My family and I have been truly traumatised by recent events and I have taken this most difficult of decisions in the best interests of my family.

"Resigning not only eases the stress and strain on them, but also offers me the opportunity to pursue justice outside the current flawed process."

RSA confirmed Smith's resignation would take effect immediately with no severance payment to be made. An RSA spokesman declined to comment.

"We continue to work constructively with the Central Bank of Ireland on this investigation," the company said, adding that the search for a new Ireland chief executive was under way.

Sources close to the company denied that there was any predetermined outcome to the investigation, and said Smith had been given the chance to co-operate with the investigation but refused.

It is understood the problems relate to the timing of the booking of large losses and earned premiums, mostly over the past two years but with some from earlier.

The insurer said this month that the problems, identified in a routine audit, were likely to wipe £70m off profits.

It also announced a capital injection that would ensure the unit's solvency ratio was "comfortably" in excess of 200%.

RSA has also appointed auditor PricewaterhouseCoopers to review the Irish operation's financial and regulatory processes and controls and its supervision by the group. Ireland's central bank has also launched an investigation.

Ireland accounts for a relatively small part of RSA, making up just 4% of group premiums last year, when the group reported an operating profit of £684m.

Nonetheless, news of the Ireland problems has hit RSA's shares and raised doubts over the future of its embattled chief executive, Simon Lee.

In February, RSA cut its annual dividend by 20%, to 7.3p a share, for last year, after complaining of poor returns from its bond investments.

Euan Stirling, a fund manager at Standard Life Investments, a major investor in RSA, has warned that Lee's "coat is on a shoogly peg … not quite nailed to the wall properly".

webTitle: Bank of England reshapes Funding for Lending; New concerns over Royal Mail float - as it happened

fields.standfirst:
• "More questions" as Goldman predicts Royal Mail shares could rise over £6
• BoE to remove household loans from Funding for Lending 
• Carney: we're protecting financial stability
• Nikkei hits highest close since December 2007
fields.body:
5.43pm GMT

Closing mini-summary

And that's all for the day.

Coverage of the Bank of England's changes to Funding for Lending start here, with Mark Carney saying the BoE is keen to guarantee financial stability,

With reaction from here.

Goldman Sachs's research note setting a 610p price target for Royal Mail - 85% higher than the float price - are here;

and the Labour Party's concerns are covered here.

While Japan's stock market rally overnight is summed up here.

I'll be back tomorrow. Until then, goodnight. GW

5.33pm GMT

The Financial Times is reporting tonight that one of the two hedge funds that were large holders of Co-op Bank's bonds have sold almost all their holding, to another fund.

 Aurelius Capital sold "virtually all its holding" to Perry Capital, a London-based hedge fund – within days of the first allegations of drug-buying emerged against ex-Co-op Bank chairman Paul Flowers, the FT says.

Here's the story.

This morning, the Co-op warned that it was finding it harder to win new current account customers since the scandal broke: Co-op Bank losing battle for new current accounts

5.19pm GMT

I began the day with the news of the Japanese stock market closing at a near six-year high. Capital Economics predict tonight that the rally has further to go.

Julian Jessop writes:

The Nikkei has now passed our end-2013 target of 15,500, closing on Thursday on 15,727. While reluctant to tweak the numbers just to chase the market higher, we see no reason why our end-2014 forecast of 16,250 cannot be reached (much) sooner than we had anticipated too.

Admittedly, the decline in the yen may now pause for breath ahead of next Friday’s crucial US employment report and the FOMC decision on 18th December, as speculation of Fed tapering could sap risk appetite again. Nonetheless, Japanese stocks should still benefit next month from the likely announcement of cuts in the corporate tax burden to help offset the impact of the consumption tax hike next April. 

5.09pm GMT

Housebuilder shares subside after FLS changes

Europe's stock markets are shut, with UK house builders leading the fallers in London.

Persimmon lost 6%, Taylor Wimpey lost 6% and Bellway and Bovis both dropped 5%, after the Bank of England announced today it was withdrawing its support for mortgage lending.

With Persimmon leading the FTSE 100 fallers, the blue chip index rose just 5 points.

Over in Germany, the DAX kept climbing to its highest ever closing price, up 36 points at 9387.

4.48pm GMT

This blog is no stranger to eurozone strikes and protests -- but today's photos of industrial action come from Germany, rather than a country in Europe's struggling periphery:

These are workers at EADS's Airbus factory in Bremen. EADS staff across Germany walked off the job today in protest at the firms restructuring plans. EADS is merging its defense and space subsidiaries, and could sell off some smaller units.

More details are due on December 5th - unions may be getting their retaliation in first. More details here

Updated at 4.49pm GMT

4.26pm GMT

Back to the Bank of England's Financial Stability Report...and Andrew Tyrie, head of the influential Treasury committee, has welcomed today's moves.

Here's the quote:

“The Bank is clearing the decks of exceptional simulative measures, put in place to encourage mortgage lending. It has also taken the opportunity to put on display some powerful weapons for reining in the market, should they subsequently be needed.

“The FPC is a new body with a vital role to play. The more detailed explanation we received today of how it will operate and the tools it may use is particularly welcome. Just as an act of signalling it can also help secure the FPC’s objectives.”

Those 'powerful weapons' include the ability to make recommendations on underwriting standards, loan to value ratios, and government's Help to Buy scheme.

4.13pm GMT

3.37pm GMT

Labour: Goldman's Royal Mail share price forecast raises more questions

Goldman Sachs' prediction this morning that Royal Mail's share price will have risen to around 610p in 12 month's time is further evidence that the postal operator's flotation may have been bungled, the Labour party has warned.

Shadow business secretary Chuka Umunna MP said the forecast undermines business secretary Vince Cable's claim that the spike from the 330p float price is 'merely froth'.

The prediction was made in research published by Goldman's equity analysts this morning. 

That 330p float price was set following advice from bankers at Goldman and UBS, who were hired to help run the float.

 Umunna said:

This raises yet more questions for ministers on their apparent failure to secure maximum value for the taxpayer in the Royal Mail fire sale.

While Vince Cable has dismissed concerns that taxpayers may have been short changed by hundreds of millions of pounds as ‘froth’, analysts at the bank which advised the deal are predicting that it could rise still further.

This comes a day after ministers’ case for the sale of Royal Mail was further undermined by the fact its profits in the first six months of this year had doubled in public ownership.

Scroll back to 10.21am post for full details of the analysis. It was published a day after Cable and business minister Michael Fallon insisted that taxpayers had not missed out.

Here's a graph from Goldman's note (which gave a 'neutral' valuation on Royal Mail), showing why it expects steady revenue growth at Royal Mail.

Royal Mail's share price is down 1.7% today, at 554p - around 67% above the 330p float price.

Adrian Bailey, chair of the BIS committee which is investigating the IPO, has suggested that Goldman Sachs could be hauled back for another grilling (managing director James Robertson appeared as a witness last week). 

Bailey told International Business Times that the 610p price tag will confirm suspicions that investment bankers had an inkling that Royal Mail was worth more than the float price of £3,3bn.

You have to question why there is this analysis now and another analysis at a much lower price that they defended vigorously only just over a week ago. What's happened that's different and what information is different now than what they had before?

Arising from this I think there are further questions that need to be asked.

The BIS committee will produce a full report on the Royal Mail float.

Updated at 3.49pm GMT

2.47pm GMT

Here's a video clip of Mark Carney announcing the changes to Funding for Lending, and the decision to stop letting banks use it for household lending.

Updated at 2.54pm GMT

2.34pm GMT

Now for the political reaction.

Cathy Jamieson MP, Labour's shadow financial secretary to the Treasury, says the changes to the Funding for Lending scheme show that it has "badly failed Britain’s businesses".

Net lending to business is down since the scheme was introduced and by over £12 billion in the last year alone.

We called for the scheme to prioritise lending to business and, after three wasted years when net lending to firms has fallen, the government is belatedly acting.

But homeowners facing a cost-of-living crisis will want reassurance from Ministers that suddenly taking the scheme away from mortgage lending won't see a rise in mortgage rates.

On that last point -- it feels likely that there will be some upward pressure on rates in future, even though Mark Carney insisted that the mortgage market doesn't need the cushion of FLS any more.

Updated at 2.55pm GMT

2.10pm GMT

Funding for Lending was a boon for UK banks because it allowed them to borrow at as little as 0.25 percentage points above the Bank's of England's base rate (0.5%).

John Longworth, Director General of the British Chambers of Commerce , says it's vital that banks use this opportunity to fund vibrant young firms with big growth potential.

They're failing on this today, he says, by cautiously backing established companies instead:

“The real test for Funding for Lending has always been whether it is able to get credit flowing to young and fast-growing companies and long term, non equity capital to firms that want to expand.

Unfortunately any improvement in credit availability is only being felt by ‘safe bets', while younger, growing firms continue to struggle to find the finance they need to expand."

Updated at 2.10pm GMT

1.56pm GMT

Q&A: The Bank of England's changes

My colleague Hilary Osborne has rattled out a Q&A on the changes announced today - it's here.

 Funding for Lending Q&A: shift in Bank of England policy

Here's a couple of points:

What does it mean for mortgages?

Funding for Lending is the reason mortgage rates have fallen to record lows this year, with lenders competing to offer the cheapest fixed-rate deals ever seen. It seems logical that taking away the cheap funding behind these deals will mean rates start to rise.

"Rates won't necessarily leap up, but you will see them ticking up," says David Hollingworth of broker London & Country. "We had already got to the point where they had bottomed out anyway."

The good news for borrowers is that funds aren't being switched off on 31 December. Banks will still be able to use their undrawn allowances for new lending, they just won't be able to apply for any more, which should mean the market does not change overnight. As of June, some of the big banks had many millions unlent, but some smaller lenders had used up their reserves.

Another positive sign is that the Council of Mortgage Lenders says funding conditions outside the scheme have improved. So it seems reasonable to expect the end of record-breaking rates without fearing massive increases.

Will I still be able to get a loan?

It might be tougher – not because of the removal of Funding for Lending, but because the BoE has also asked the regulator to enforce what could be tougher affordability tests on mortgage lending.

1.46pm GMT

Marc Ostwald of Monument Securities reckoned today's changes are "not a nail in the coffin" for the Help to Buy mortgage subsidy scheme. Instead, it's:

a) the shape of things to come on central bank policy, and happens so often, flagged up by introduction of similar policies in New Zealand, and very much along the lines of what Carney did in Canada,
b) it goes to prove that the FLS has been far more effective than the feckless "spaghetti principle' of QE,
c) not an admission of a bubble, but more a sharp admonition to banks about lax standards on mortgage lending. 

1.44pm GMT

More reaction....

Carl Astorri, senior economic adviser to the EY ITEM Club, points out that mortgage lending is up 40% since August 2012, compared to just 15% for business lending.

He welcomed the "greater prudence" from the Bank, especially as the latest assessment of the UK economy in the last quarter showed business investment was lagging:

 Given the subdued recovery in business investment, as is evident from the Q3 expenditure breakdown, the move to reorient FLS towards businesses appears well-timed.” 

1.24pm GMT

Mark Carney will be near the top of the Federation of Small Businesses' Christmas card list.

Their national chairman, John Allan, gives the governor the credit for deciding to focus Funding for Lending at SMEs, saying:

This is a surprising yet refreshing announcement which will make a difference to lending to thousands of our members and millions of small firms. It is something the FSB has raised with the Governor of the Bank of England and he is clearly listening.

It is encouraging that he has recognised the contribution small firms make to job creation and the real economy has been given priority over the housing market, which is receiving assistance in other areas such as Help to Buy. FLS has already helped to reduce the cost of finance for businesses. What we now need is to see a focus on increasing the number of firms getting access to the finance they need to grow.”

1.21pm GMT

Key event

Howard Archer, chief economist at IHS Global Insight, has welcomed the decision to stop letting banks use the FLS to subsidise household lending.

He called it "a hugely sensible and justifiable move taken by the Bank of England:, adding:

With the Help to Buy mortgage guarantee scheme only just starting to kick in and interest rates likely to stay extremely low for some time to come, there is still substantial support to the housing market even in the absence of any further support from the FLS. Furthermore, overall markedly improved consumer confidence and rising employment is likely to continue to support housing market activity.

Archer also argued that "there is little evidence of a housing bubble outside of London", as October's Land Registry data showed prices fell 0.2%. 

House prices were up 8.7% year-on-year in London but outside London and the South East (up 4.0%), no other region saw annual house price growth in excess of 4.0% in October, and prices were still falling year-on-year in the North West (down 0.7%) and North East (down 0.8%). 

12.54pm GMT

TUC welcomes changes to funding scheme

TUC General Secretary Frances O’Grady has welcomed the move, calling it

...good news for the real economy, but bad news for the Chancellor.

The Bank of England is clearly worried that the economic recovery is based on consumers borrowing on the back of rising house prices rather than business investment and rising exports.

Ensuring that funding for lending works to boost business investment is a sensible policy that can drive sustainable growth and help build a new economy. But stopping over-excitement in the property market may hit the feel-good factor that the Chancellor is hoping will distract from the failure of government policy to rebalance the economy. 

The TUC's invaluable economist, Duncan Weldon, has also written a fuller explanation here:

Funding for Lending: A Big & Important Change

In it, he argues that household borrowing has been a major factor in the UK recovery, with people taking advantage of easier credit conditions and the fact they felt wealthier due to house price rises.

Our recovery to date has been focussed on rising consumption underpinned by rising household borrowing. Today’s action from the Bank may well cool it.

The hope is that business investment will kick in as a more solid component of growth –although that has yet to really begin.

Weldon also suspects that the Bank, rather than the Treasury, is the driving force behind the changes.

12.42pm GMT

The pound has hit a 14-month high against a basket of currencies, including an 11-month high of $1.635 against the US dollar.

12.41pm GMT

Osborne: more help needed for lending

Chancellor George Osborne tweeted that today's changes are being made because lending to businesses still isn't "good enough" 

As mentioned earlier, Mark Carney said the changes to FLS were made jointly between the Treasury and the Bank - trying to avoid any impression of a row between the two sides. 

Updated at 12.41pm GMT

12.34pm GMT

Simon Nixon of the Wall Street Journal isn't impressed with Mark Carney's argument that the Bank will be able to maintain easy monetary policy for longer:

12.28pm GMT

Jill Treanor's full story on the Bank of England's changes is updated, and online here:

Bank of England refocuses FLS away from mortgages

11.59am GMT

Finally, Ed Conway of Sky News seeks more clarity on the Bank's powers on LTVs - the Loan to Value ratios which lenders use when assessing the suitability of a potential borrower and how much they should lend.

Would you rather have the power to make a direction on LTV ratios, rather than a recommendation?

Carney says that Bank has a wide range of tools, and as he sits here today he feels they are "considerable" and should be adequate.

He cautions, though, that this is based on the belief that if the Bank made a recommendation on LTV it would be followed.

And again, the governor reiterates that there's a considerable toolkit to hand, we've used a proportion of it in a proportionate way. And he stresses that the Bank would used its powers in a calibrated way - he wouldn't just deploy them once.

Updated at 12.00pm GMT

11.52am GMT

Another question about Scottish independence. 

Carney says he has not had a meeting yet with the Scottish government, although his predecessor (Mervyn King) did have some some "very basic discussions with Mr [Alex] Salmond" in the last couple of years.

I would welcome the opportunity for a meeting, Carney adds.

So why has a meeting not happened? 

They've been busy writing their report*...I've been busy... There has been an effort to set up a meeting, and I'm sure it will happen, Carney adds.

* - the 600-plus page White Paper published this week.

Updated at 12.00pm GMT

11.49am GMT

Claire Jones of the FT challenges Carney on whether the Bank can be confidence that the relatively untested tools for financial stability will work as they hope.

Carney replies that went through through a housing bust when he lived in the UK before (he studied at Oxford in the early 1990s). I know the damage that can be done if the market is left unchecked, he adds.

The governor insists that today's changes, and the remaining tools at the BOE's disposal, are sensible. Why would we stand by and let mortgage underwriting standards fall? Why should we provide funding to underpin a housing market when it's no longer necessary?

And he repeats that the changes will help maintain accommodative monetary policy for longer. 

11.41am GMT

11.40am GMT

My colleague Jill Treanor asks Andrew Bailey about the situation at Co-op Bank.

Bailey says that standards of governance over bank appointments has been tightened up since Paul Flowers joined the Co-op board and was later 'informally' interviewed to become chairman.

Today, the process is "very different", Bailey insists. Senior people at the BoE are much more closely involved.. "I would be involved".

He adde that the Bank of England required a restructuring of the Co-op Bank's board while Flowers was chairman. 

And on the Co-op's disastrous bid for Lloyds Branches, Bailey says he didn't know the full story - which is why an inquiry is needed - but he says the Bank of England acted properly by stating its concerns over Co-op's capital levels.

He concludes that it is the £1.5bn capital black hole at Co-op that caused the current situation , not the Reverend Flowers "antics".

Updated at 12.35pm GMT

11.30am GMT

Another question on the impact on the mortgage market.

Carney says that the Bank still sees "near-term momentum" in mortgage approvals and prices. 

It's partly demand driven -- people feel more confidence about job prospects. there's pent-up demand, perhaps because of marriages or children. "All the reasons people move house".

11.26am GMT

Mark Carney declines to answer a question on Scottish independence, on whether he's worried that the Bank could become the lender of last resort to a bank it doesn't directly regulate.

It's not right to give a couple of sentences on this issue, he says -- we'll present our "technocratic, boring" position properly in the right venue at the right time.

Updated at 11.27am GMT

11.22am GMT

In the financial markets, shares in British housebuilders have tumbled since the news broke.

Persimmon and Taylor Wimpey are both down 7%.

Investors may be calculating that the changes to Funding for Lending, and the prospect of tighter rules on mortgage lending in the future, will hit house builders profits.

11.16am GMT

The decision to remove mortgage lending from the Funding for Lending Scheme (which allows banks to borrow from the BoE at generous terms) was taken jointly with chancellor George Osborne, Carney says.

11.14am GMT

A question about the claims that Royal Bank of Scotland deliberately undermined, or even destroyed, its own small business customers.

Deputy governor Andrew Bailey says there must be serious investigation of these very serious allegations, but that this must not distract from looking into the wider issue of the mechanics of lending to SMEs.

11.10am GMT

Explaining the decision to remove mortgages from the Funding for Lending Scheme, Mark Carney adds that it's no longer appropriate or necessary to have the foot on the accelerator; better to move into neutral.

Updated at 11.18am GMT

11.10am GMT

Does Mark Carney agree that Funding for Lending has been a main factor in driving house prices up? And what's the consequence of today's changes?

The governor replies that he "does not expect a material change" to the market. When FLS was brought in, there was extreme stress on bank funding. There has been marked improvement since then, so it acts mainly as a "backstop".

11.04am GMT

Carney: It's all about the financial stability

Governor Carney makes a key point -- that if the Financial Policy Committee does its job, of protecting that financial stability of the UK, it will be easier for the Monetary Policy Committee to maintain extremely accommodative monetary policy to secure the recovery.

In other words, prevent a housing bubble today and we can keep interest rates low tomorrow.

11.02am GMT

Carney explains that Bank is developing various new tools for the mortgage market.

It is consulting on a tool which would mean that the FPC could instruct banks and building societies immediately change the long-term forecasts for interest rates which they use when assessing affordability.

So if the FPC saw a risk of higher rates in the money markets in five years, it could make banks take that into account.

11.01am GMT

The press conference is being streamed here, btw (sorry for not adding the link sooner).

10.59am GMT

10.55am GMT

Is the government's Help to Buy scheme (which provides subsidies to some borrowers) making financial stability worse?

Carney says that Help to Buy is still at its early stage. The Bank can provide advice to the Government if it should conclude that it is a threat to stability.

Updated at 10.56am GMT

10.51am GMT

Carney is reminded that the Bank has played down the idea of risks in the housing market in previous statements.

The governor replies that the market is still not booming -- mortgages approvals are still at three-quarters of their pre-crisis high. 

We don't want to risk a deterioration in underwriting standards for mortgages, he adds.

Updated at 10.53am GMT

10.50am GMT

Mark Carney is taking questions at the Bank of England press conference on its financial stability report, and the decision to stop banks using Funding for Lending Scheme to fund mortgages. 

Richard Edgar of ITV goes first -- is the Bank making these changes because it's worried about house prices?

Carney replies that the Bank doesn't see "an immediate threat", but an "evolving threat".

"The concern is where this could go", Carney explains, adding that prices have risen from a relatively high base already.

10.43am GMT

From the Bank of England, Jill Treanor reports:

The Bank of England on Thursday took the first steps to ensure a housing bubble does not emerge by removing some of the stimulus from mortgage market.

While stressing that the housing market is not immediate risk to financial stability, the Bank is forcing banks to hold more capital against mortgage lending through existing guarantee schemes.

The annual heath check of Britain's banks being introduced next year will also require banks to look at their resilience to housing shocks. And the Bank's financial policy committee -set up to look for the next
bubbles in the financial system - is also requiring the Financial Conduct Authority to force banks to embark on tougher tests when deciding if a customer can afford a mortgage.

In a letter to Chancellor George Osborne, the Bank's governor Mark Carney set out the changes to the funding for lending (fls) scheme which has led to a fall in bank funding costs since it was introduced in July 2012. Carney said that the fls would try to focus more on lending to the business sector and a relaxation in capital rules that had been applied to mortgage lending would be removed.

"Although the growth in household loan volumes remain modest, activity is picking up and house price momentum appears to be gaining momentum," Carney told the Chancellor.

However there are no changes to the help to buy scheme which the Bank will assess annually from 2014 and in its half yearly check on the risks to financial stability, the Bank said there was not a risk to the financial system from the housing market.

More to follow....

Updated at 10.57am GMT

10.40am GMT

Bank of England revises Funding For Lending

BIG NEWS: The Bank of England is revising its Funding For Lending Scheme to focus on small businesses, rather than to fund mortgage lending.

It means that, from next year, banks will not be able to use the Funding For Lending Scheme to support mortgage loans.

Governor Mark Carney is explaining that the change will help to reinforce financial stability, and that the UK mortgage sector no longer needs this specific help. It is also a response to evolving risks in the housing market, he says.

By acting now in a graduated fashion, we are lowering the risk that a larger intervenion will be needed in future, says Carney at a press conference in London.

The news comes as the BoE publishes its financial stability report.

Here's the announcement.

Updated at 10.46am GMT

10.27am GMT

Nearly time for Bank of England Governor Mark Carney to present his first Financial Stability Report - it should hit the wires at 10.30am....

10.21am GMT

Goldman Sachs sets 610p price target on Royal Mail

Goldman Sachs has added to concerns over the Royal Mail privatisation by setting a 12-month target for its shares of 610p this morning.

That's an 85% premium on the 330p share price which the government floated the postal operator in October, a deal in which Goldman Sachs investment bankers played a role. 

If Goldman's Equity Research team are right, Royal Mail have a stock market valuation of more than £6bn in a year's time, compared to the £3.3bn it was valued at in October's float.

Shares in Royal Mail rallied to 565p yesterday after it reported a doubling in profits for its last six months as a public company.

Goldman, which gave Royal Mail a "neutral" valuation, believes it will rise around 8% over the next year. 

In the 53-page analyst note, Goldman said that Royal Mail should benefit from "network modernisation and labour force rationalisation" in future years, and also predicted that the firm's margins should improve.

Goldman added that its valuation did not include the risk of a strike action, as "we now view the near-term strike risk as relatively low".

Ministers have blamed the threat of industrial action as one factor which meant City investors would not pay over 330p per share. 

The analysts who produced today's note are quite separate from the bankers who advised the government.

Here's Goldman's investment view: 

With c.50% of its revenues coming from growth-exposed parcel markets, an extensive UK Core Network asset providing a competitive cost advantage, and margin upside opportunity from productivity improvements, we believe Royal Mail (RMG) is well-placed to deliver a double-digit EBIT CAGR [Compound Annual Growth Rate] of 17.5% over four years.

We expect further network modernisation and labour force rationalisation to drive the EBIT margin to 7.5% in FY17E (from 4.4% FY13). We forecast a progressive dividend payout ratio, from 56% (FY14E), rising to 65% in FY17E. We initiate with a Neutral rating given limited sector-relative upside.

Core drivers of growth

We expect the 32% of sales coming from UK parcels to deliver good revenue growth, driven by online retail spend and Royal Mail Group’s unique competitive advantage afforded it by a dual-use core network.

With further modest growth coming from EU parcels (via GLS, 16% of sales) we expect group parcel growth to more than offset continued letter volume declines. We forecast network modernisation (parcel automation and logistics optimisation) to drive productivity improvements and facilitate headcount reduction, delivering further margin improvement .

But there are risks, as ministers have pointed out in their defence of the IPO...

Risks to the investment case

Key risks include the competitive threat from Access operators, regulatory changes, letter volume declines and VAT exemption-loss. 

Yesterday, Business secretary Vince Cable insisted that Royal Mail had not been sold too cheaply. But members of the Business, Innovations and Skills committee fear that the government was "conned" by its investment bankers.

Goldman and UBS were hired to help run the flotation, including the "fishing expedition" to find how much City investors would pay for Royal Mail shares in the float.

Here's some more detail from the report:

Updated at 10.24am GMT

9.20am GMT

Germany's seasonally unemployment rate remains at 6.9% in November, the country's Federal Labour Office reports.

But the total number of people out of work rose by more than expected -- by 10,000, versus forecasts of 1,000. That pushed the seasonally adjusted jobless total up to 2.985m, from 2.975m in October, to the highest total since April 2011.

If you don't adjust for seasonal factors, the unemployment total rose by 5,000 people this month to 2.806m (giving an unadjusted jobless rate of 6.5%).

9.11am GMT

On the German coalition deal, Open Europe analyst Nina Schick reckons it will make little difference to the country's approach to the eurozone.

Writing in City AM, she argues that the agreement means " Germany is still Germany. And Merkel is still queen of Europe".

Here's why: 

On the Eurozone and the wider EU question, as always, the German rhetoric is strongly in favour of further EU integration, with the agreement calling it “the most important task facing Germany”. However, it also rejects all forms of debt pooling. This confirms, once again, that when the Germans talk of more integration, they mean stronger central control over taxation and spending, not fiscal and political union. A recent Open Europe poll showed that 64 per cent of Germans oppose debt mutualisation.

And despite language promoting “growth” and “competitiveness”, ultimately the agreement concludes that austerity and consolidation of national budgets remains the main remedy to exit the crisis, albeit with more emphasis on structural reform.

The coalition has also committed to new “reform contracts”, where struggling euro countries will agree to structural reforms in exchange for further aid. This is an idea floated by Merkel in the lead up to the elections, and is politically feasible for the Germans, as it involves more control over Eurozone spending and reforms for potentially less cash. Unlike debt pooling or yet more ad hoc rescue packages, Merkel might get it past her bailout-fatigued public. However, making these contracts enforceable could set Germany up for a major battle.

Finally, on the much-heralded banking union, there’s little detail, although the agreement does say that the banking sector itself will pay in the event of crisis. But make no mistake, progress will remain very slow.

9.05am GMT

German DAX hits another record

The German stock market has hit yet another record high this morning, as it's been doing repeatedly in recent weeks.

Not a big move -- the DAX is up just 0.2%, or 20 points, to 9371, in a mood of mild optimism over the German coalition government deal agreed yesterday.

On that, finance minister Wolfgang Schäuble has been discussing the plan agreed between his CDU/CSU party and the Social Democrats.

Reuters has the details:

Schäuble said on Thursday that plans for additional spending of €23bn euros outlined in a new coalition deal were realistic and could be financed, partly with the help of hidden reserves.

"This is a cautious, realistic but of course ambitious plan," Schäuble told German radio, adding it would not be possible to finance more ambitious spending plans proposed by the Social Democrats (SPD).

Chancellor Angela Merkel's conservatives, of which Schäuble is a member, agreed a coalition deal with the SPD in the early hours of Wednesday although SPD members still have to vote for the agreement for it to take effect.

The plan includes a lower retirement age for some workers and a minimum wage of €8.50/hour (which were both key SPD demands), and an agreement that overall taxes won't rise (as sought by the CDU).

Updated at 9.05am GMT

8.50am GMT

Wolseley, the FTSE 100 plumbing and building suppliers firm, has also reported tough times in the French market.

Like-for-like revenue in France fell by 4.8% in the three months to the end of October, which it blamed on continued weakness in the new residential market and "negligible" inflation.

In the Nordic region, comparable revenues were down 2.6%, and they fell by 2.9% in Central Europe. On a happier note for the company -- which is a good measure of demand in the housing market - they rose 7% in the US and 4% in the UK.

The statement's online here.

8.38am GMT

Retail group Kingfisher has been bruised by France's weak economy.

It told shareholders this morning that it sees no signs of improvement in consumer morale in France - a key area for the company - underlining how the eurozone's second-largest member is struggling.

Kingfisher's profits in France shrank by 5.6% in the last three months, taking the shine off an 8.3% rise in profits in UK and Ireland.

Chief executive Ian Cheshire said:

Whilst we have delivered sales growth in each of our geographies our markets remain challenging, especially in France where consumer confidence is still weak and with no obvious signs of an imminent improvement.

Galling news for shareholders -- who sent Kingfisher's shares sliding over 5% this morning to the bottom of the FTSE 100.

8.26am GMT

Confirmation that Spain's recession is over, and that its recovery is rather weak.

Official data released this morning showed that GDP grew by 0.1% in the third quarter of the year, in line with the initial estimate. On an annual basis, the Spanish economy remains 1.1% smaller than a year ago.

8.24am GMT

Here's how the Nikkei's performance over the last five years:

And today's best performers:

8.08am GMT

Japan's Nikkei at highest level since December 2007

Good morning, and welcome to our rolling coverage of events across the financial markets, the world economy, the eurozone and the business world. 

Let's start with Japan, where the Nikkei stock market index of the biggest Japanese companies has just finished at its highest closing level in almost six years.

Shares in Japanese manufacturers rose pretty strongly today, as the value of the yen against the dollar fell back -- boosting hopes that exports will benefit.

Asia is also taking its cue from Wall Street, where the Dow and the S&P 500 indices also closed at record high last night.

More grist to the mill of those who fear that global stock markets have been driven too high, given the tender state of the global recovery....

..but enough to send the Nikkei bounding 1.8% higher to 15727.12, a closing level not seen since the end of 2007, as the financial crisis began.

The yen fell as low as ¥102.27 against the US dollar, further over the 100 yen mark seen as important for the Tokyo government's plan to stimulate growth and inflation.

As Hiroyuki Fukunaga, the chief executive of Investrust, put it:

The yen's weakness is lifting hopes for even higher profits for exporters this fiscal year.

The US dollar strengthened after generally decent economic out of America last night; some economists believe the Federal Reserve is closer to slowing its bond-buying stimulus programme.

Reuters explains:

"The U.S. economic data were very pro-tapering, despite the weakness in the durable goods data," Steven Englander, global head of G10 FX strategy at Citigroup, wrote in a note.

The Indonesian rupiah fell to its psychological support at 12,000 per dollar, the first time since March 2009. The currency is seen vulnerable to capital outflows once the U.S. Federal Reserve begins dialling back the massive stimulus that has fuelled asset prices in emerging markets. 

And there was a general air of optimism across the region, according to IG's man in Melbourne, Stan Shamu:

Asia is enjoying a solid day after US equities remained at all-time highs heading into the Thanksgiving holiday. Japan is leading a buoyant session in Asia after a fresh round of yen weakness.

This also saw the Chinese CSI index rose 1%.

Also coming up today…

The Bank of England's financial policy committee will release its latest assessment of the stability of the UK economy, at 10.30am. Governor Mark Carney will hold a press conference.

And there's various economic data to digest -- including:

• German unemployment data, and inflation data (1pm GMT)

• the European Commission's economic sentiment survey for November (10am GMT)

I'll also try to take a closer look on the impact of yesterday's German coalition deal on the euro area (something that got neglected yesterday as I was buried under a blizzard of Royal Mail news)…..

Updated at 8.14am GMT
fields.bodyText: And that's all for the day. Coverage of the Bank of England's changes to Funding for Lending start here, with Mark Carney saying the BoE is keen to guarantee financial stability, With reaction from here. Goldman Sachs's research note setting a 610p price target for Royal Mail - 85% higher than the float price - are here; and the Labour Party's concerns are covered here. While Japan's stock market rally overnight is summed up here. I'll be back tomorrow. Until then, goodnight. GW The Financial Times is reporting tonight that one of the two hedge funds that were large holders of Co-op Bank's bonds have sold almost all their holding, to another fund. Aurelius Capital sold "virtually all its holding" to Perry Capital, a London-based hedge fund – within days of the first allegations of drug-buying emerged against ex-Co-op Bank chairman Paul Flowers, the FT says. Here's the story. This morning, the Co-op warned that it was finding it harder to win new current account customers since the scandal broke: Co-op Bank losing battle for new current accounts I began the day with the news of the Japanese stock market closing at a near six-year high. Capital Economics predict tonight that the rally has further to go. Julian Jessop writes: The Nikkei has now passed our end-2013 target of 15,500, closing on Thursday on 15,727. While reluctant to tweak the numbers just to chase the market higher, we see no reason why our end-2014 forecast of 16,250 cannot be reached (much) sooner than we had anticipated too. Admittedly, the decline in the yen may now pause for breath ahead of next Friday’s crucial US employment report and the FOMC decision on 18th December, as speculation of Fed tapering could sap risk appetite again. Nonetheless, Japanese stocks should still benefit next month from the likely announcement of cuts in the corporate tax burden to help offset the impact of the consumption tax hike next April. Europe's stock markets are shut, with UK house builders leading the fallers in London. Persimmon lost 6%, Taylor Wimpey lost 6% and Bellway and Bovis both dropped 5%, after the Bank of England announced today it was withdrawing its support for mortgage lending. With Persimmon leading the FTSE 100 fallers, the blue chip index rose just 5 points. Over in Germany, the DAX kept climbing to its highest ever closing price, up 36 points at 9387. This blog is no stranger to eurozone strikes and protests -- but today's photos of industrial action come from Germany, rather than a country in Europe's struggling periphery: These are workers at EADS's Airbus factory in Bremen. EADS staff across Germany walked off the job today in protest at the firms restructuring plans. EADS is merging its defense and space subsidiaries, and could sell off some smaller units. More details are due on December 5th - unions may be getting their retaliation in first. More details here Back to the Bank of England's Financial Stability Report...and Andrew Tyrie, head of the influential Treasury committee, has welcomed today's moves. Here's the quote: “The Bank is clearing the decks of exceptional simulative measures, put in place to encourage mortgage lending. It has also taken the opportunity to put on display some powerful weapons for reining in the market, should they subsequently be needed. “The FPC is a new body with a vital role to play. The more detailed explanation we received today of how it will operate and the tools it may use is particularly welcome. Just as an act of signalling it can also help secure the FPC’s objectives.” Those 'powerful weapons' include the ability to make recommendations on underwriting standards, loan to value ratios, and government's Help to Buy scheme. Goldman Sachs' prediction this morning that Royal Mail's share price will have risen to around 610p in 12 month's time is further evidence that the postal operator's flotation may have been bungled, the Labour party has warned. Shadow business secretary Chuka Umunna MP said the forecast undermines business secretary Vince Cable's claim that the spike from the 330p float price is 'merely froth'. The prediction was made in research published by Goldman's equity analysts this morning. That 330p float price was set following advice from bankers at Goldman and UBS, who were hired to help run the float. Umunna said: This raises yet more questions for ministers on their apparent failure to secure maximum value for the taxpayer in the Royal Mail fire sale. While Vince Cable has dismissed concerns that taxpayers may have been short changed by hundreds of millions of pounds as ‘froth’, analysts at the bank which advised the deal are predicting that it could rise still further. This comes a day after ministers’ case for the sale of Royal Mail was further undermined by the fact its profits in the first six months of this year had doubled in public ownership. Scroll back to 10.21am post for full details of the analysis. It was published a day after Cable and business minister Michael Fallon insisted that taxpayers had not missed out. Here's a graph from Goldman's note (which gave a 'neutral' valuation on Royal Mail), showing why it expects steady revenue growth at Royal Mail. Royal Mail's share price is down 1.7% today, at 554p - around 67% above the 330p float price. Adrian Bailey, chair of the BIS committee which is investigating the IPO, has suggested that Goldman Sachs could be hauled back for another grilling (managing director James Robertson appeared as a witness last week). Bailey told International Business Times that the 610p price tag will confirm suspicions that investment bankers had an inkling that Royal Mail was worth more than the float price of £3,3bn. You have to question why there is this analysis now and another analysis at a much lower price that they defended vigorously only just over a week ago. What's happened that's different and what information is different now than what they had before? Arising from this I think there are further questions that need to be asked. The BIS committee will produce a full report on the Royal Mail float. Here's a video clip of Mark Carney announcing the changes to Funding for Lending, and the decision to stop letting banks use it for household lending. Now for the political reaction. Cathy Jamieson MP, Labour's shadow financial secretary to the Treasury, says the changes to the Funding for Lending scheme show that it has "badly failed Britain’s businesses". Net lending to business is down since the scheme was introduced and by over £12 billion in the last year alone. We called for the scheme to prioritise lending to business and, after three wasted years when net lending to firms has fallen, the government is belatedly acting. But homeowners facing a cost-of-living crisis will want reassurance from Ministers that suddenly taking the scheme away from mortgage lending won't see a rise in mortgage rates. On that last point -- it feels likely that there will be some upward pressure on rates in future, even though Mark Carney insisted that the mortgage market doesn't need the cushion of FLS any more. Funding for Lending was a boon for UK banks because it allowed them to borrow at as little as 0.25 percentage points above the Bank's of England's base rate (0.5%). John Longworth, Director General of the British Chambers of Commerce , says it's vital that banks use this opportunity to fund vibrant young firms with big growth potential. They're failing on this today, he says, by cautiously backing established companies instead: “The real test for Funding for Lending has always been whether it is able to get credit flowing to young and fast-growing companies and long term, non equity capital to firms that want to expand. Unfortunately any improvement in credit availability is only being felt by ‘safe bets', while younger, growing firms continue to struggle to find the finance they need to expand." My colleague Hilary Osborne has rattled out a Q&A on the changes announced today - it's here. Funding for Lending Q&A: shift in Bank of England policy Here's a couple of points: What does it mean for mortgages? Funding for Lending is the reason mortgage rates have fallen to record lows this year, with lenders competing to offer the cheapest fixed-rate deals ever seen. It seems logical that taking away the cheap funding behind these deals will mean rates start to rise. "Rates won't necessarily leap up, but you will see them ticking up," says David Hollingworth of broker London & Country. "We had already got to the point where they had bottomed out anyway." The good news for borrowers is that funds aren't being switched off on 31 December. Banks will still be able to use their undrawn allowances for new lending, they just won't be able to apply for any more, which should mean the market does not change overnight. As of June, some of the big banks had many millions unlent, but some smaller lenders had used up their reserves. Another positive sign is that the Council of Mortgage Lenders says funding conditions outside the scheme have improved. So it seems reasonable to expect the end of record-breaking rates without fearing massive increases. Will I still be able to get a loan? Marc Ostwald of Monument Securities reckoned today's changes are "not a nail in the coffin" for the Help to Buy mortgage subsidy scheme.
